title: Question 52

children: A 45-year-old asymptomatic man is evaluated during a routine wellness examination. His mother recently died of metastatic colon cancer. She was diagnosed with colon cancer 5 years ago at age 69 years; there is no other history of familial polyps, colon cancer, or other cancer diagnoses.
Which of the following is the most appropriate colorectal cancer screening strategy for this patient?

Appropriate screening strategies for colorectal cancer in average-risk individuals include colonoscopy every 10 years; high-sensitivity guaiac fecal occult blood test or fecal immunochemical test every year; DNA-fecal immunochemical test every 1 to 3 years; CT colonography every 5 years; flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years; and flexible sigmoidoscopy every 10 years plus fecal immunochemical testing every year.

) is the most appropriate colorectal cancer (CRC) screening strategy for this patient at average risk for colorectal cancer. Evidence from cohort studies demonstrated that colonoscopy reduces CRC-related mortality. Colonoscopy every 10 years is the longest screening interval of all recommended colorectal cancer screening tests. Harms include bleeding and perforation, both risks increasing with age. Other acceptable screening strategies include high-sensitivity guaiac fecal occult blood test or fecal immunochemical test every year; DNA-fecal immunochemical test every 1 to 3 years; CT colonography every 5 years; flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years; and flexible sigmoidoscopy every 10 years plus fecal immunochemical testing every year. The most appropriate CRC screening strategy is the strategy the patient is most likely to adhere.

) is an appropriate screening test and interval for patients at increased risk for CRC. Patients at increased risk have a family history of CRC diagnosed in a first-degree relative at younger than 60 years or with two or more first-degree relatives at any age. In these patients, CRC screening should begin at age 40 years or 10 years earlier than the age of the youngest first-degree relative at diagnosis, whichever comes first. This patient has average risk for CRC and screening every 10 years with colonoscopy is appropriate.

) screening for CRC should be performed every 5 years in average-risk patients, rather than every 10 years. There is no direct evidence that CT colonography reduces CRC mortality. CT colonography requires the same bowel preparation as colonoscopy. Abnormal colonography results must be followed up with colonoscopy.

) should be performed annually, rather than every 5 years. Evidence from a single large cohort study documents a reduction in CRC with annual screening. Testing can be done with a single stool specimen but does not require bowel preparation. Abnormal results must be followed up with colonoscopy.

objective.__html: Screen for colorectal cancer with the most appropriate strategy.

references: Davidson KW, Barry MJ, Mangione CM, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for colorectal cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2021;325:1965-1977.
